abstract: In these are dire times for Detroit’s automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of auto-parts suppliers, why are big name investors like Carl C. Icahn, Wilbur L. Ross and Cerberus Capital pouring their cash into what seems like a losing proposition? The answer, suggests The New York Times, is that, while business for auto suppliers has evaporated in Detroit, it is expanding in the rest of the world as vehicle sales increase globally. Of course, the cheap price tags and low interest rates are not hurting either.
lead_paragraph: In these are dire times for Detroit’s automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of auto-parts suppliers, why are big name investors like Carl C. Icahn, Wilbur L. The answer, suggests The New York Times, is that, while business for auto suppliers has evaporated in Detroit, it is expanding in the rest of the world as vehicle sales increase globally. Of course, the cheap price tags and low interest rates are not hurting either.

headline.main: Big Investors Bail Out Gasping Auto Parts Suppliers
